Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Cloud-based Simulated Patients for Rapid Competency Development in Medical Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II award proposes to enhance the technical understanding of how to create rich, high-performance, entirely cloud-based applications that are accessed anytime, anywhere on any device. The layered Web application architecture eliminates the need for a local application or proprietary browser plug-ins like Java or Flash. The framework will provide complex interface components and powerful functionality in interface composition, styling, dynamic behavior and data manipulation. Benefits include: 1) Smooth, seamless local application-like user experience independent of user platform, 2) Lower support costs as all business logic is deployed in the cloud, 3) Improved security as the server validates all actions so if client data is tampered with, the server can detect it and react accordingly, 4) Simpler yet more powerful application programming model, closer to GUI software development than traditional Web development, 5) Ability to deliver complex computation and storage-intensive functionality to mobile platforms, and 6) Integration of real-time collaboration without local and proprietary installation requirements.



The broader/commercial impact of the simulated patient service is driven by enabling medical educators to accelerate development of students' clinical competencies in an affordable and scalable manner, helping to address the widely anticipated shortage of qualified U.S. providers driven by the aging of the Baby Boomers and an expected 15% increase in demand for healthcare services due to coverage of the previously uninsured. Shortages in developing countries are even greater. The service will also help ensure the quality of medical education and lower the cost of healthcare as mastery of critical diagnostic reasoning is the basis for efficient delivery of care and is required for optimal outcomes, cost control and reduction of hospital readmissions. If used in testing, certification, continuing medical education, and protocol adherence, it could ensure the competency of recruits, help busy clinicians keep up with advances in medical knowledge, and identify those in need of additional or remedial training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diagnostic reasoning errors in the U.S. are both common and costly. Five to 15% of adult outpatients in the U.S. are misdiagnosed. Studies also indicate that misdiagnosis results in 40,000 to 80,000 deaths in the US annually with autopsy studies showing 5% of patients die of a diagnosis that was missed and could have been treated had it been diagnosed pre-mortem. Diagnostic errors are responsible for a portion of the estimated $700 billion in unnecessary, avoidable costs due to unwarranted variations in care. Diagnostic errors also result in the largest malpractice payouts.

A recent IOM report (September, 2015) concluded that every one of us is likely to experience a significant diagnostic error in our lifetime, sometimes with devastating consequences. The report’s leading recommendation is to enhance health care professional education and training in the diagnostic process. The content of this proposal will address this.

The leading clinical reasoning errors that contribute to malpractice claims include a) failure to obtain an adequate history, b) failure to conduct an appropriate physical exam, c) failure to order appropriate tests, and finally, d) failure to properly interpret tests. Another study demonstrated that diagnostic errors contributed to 74% of the errors in cases. These errors included faulty differential synthesis, premature case closure, and misinterpretation of salient physical or test findings. Finally, a review of malpractice claims found that the most common failures of technical competence occurred in diagnostic-decision making.

Diagnostic reasoning errors may reflect shortcomings in the current education and evaluation process. Traditionally, diagnostic reasoning has been taught primarily through mentorship. However, this approach has serious limitations due to the current changes in healthcare delivery such that:

 

  • Many clinician-educators lack training and skill to explicitly communicate their thought processes.
  • Clinical problem solving skills are often content-specific, yet the random array of patients encountered may not provide the optimal mix of clinical material to develop the necessary breadth of knowledge or experience, especially as hospital stays are shortened and more clinical problems are diagnosed and treated as outpatients.
  • Resident work hour limitations substantially decrease patient contact time.
  • Physician team-based approaches often deprive providers of the opportunity to determine the accuracy of their initial diagnoses or the outcomes of their therapeutic choices.

 

One factor underlying diagnostic reasoning errors may be the curricular focus on disease pathophysiology, without an adequate focus on a patient’s presenting clinical symptoms. Providers often look at the finding of a diagnosis as the conclusion of the clinical reasoning process, which further reinforces early closure and a limited differential.

Another contributor to diagnostic errors is the emphasis on the prototypical presentations of diseases. While expert clinicians are aware of the continuum of clinical presentations, they often fail to consider diagnoses because of the misconception that patients will present in these archetypal ways. This often leads to not considering or erroneously excluding a diagnosis from consideration when patients present with just a few subtle symptoms or findings. Research has found that only 20% of 337 classical findings for 101 diseases were more than 80% sensitive for diagnosis of those diseases. This suggests that many patients lack “classic symptoms,” which may lead inappropriately to prematurely excluding diseases from consideration. Classical descriptions often fail to emphasize the specificity of the physical findings and their salience in patient evaluation. As an example, less than half (47%) of the prototypical signs of diseases that are frequently taught had a > 90% specificity. These data suggest that educators should focus on signs with high specificity and use the presence or absence of these signs to more accurately and rapidly focus the diagnostic search.

Given the high current rate of diagnostic error, it is clear that a new pedagogical approach is needed.

This NSF sponsored project developed a system for authoring and delivering virtual patient encounters that simulate the comprehensive set of cognitive skills required to assess and diagnose a patient. Specifically, the system:

  • Provides an adequate breadth and depth of clinical content
  • Provides a mechanism for engaging learners in authentic clinical cases and contexts
  • Provides high-quality, specific and actionable feedback, based on a sound clinical evidence base
  • Supports comprehensive competency reporting analytics to focus individual and group learning and improvement
  • Is scalable, allowing it to reach enough learners to impact population-level outcomes

This system improves medical readiness by demonstrating the efficacy of a system built to teach and assess diagnostic reasoning competencies. The case content is highly configurable to suit varying learning objectives and provides individualized, objective, evidence-based feedback to prepare medical providers to rapidly diagnose and treat real-world patient problems.
